title-group.article-title: Association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms in adults with diagnosed sleep disorders: an analysis of NHANES 2007–2018 data

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: This study aimed to examine the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms in adults diagnosed with sleep disorders, and to explore the potential of recreational physical activity as a practical intervention to alleviate depressive symptoms.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Data were drawn from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) between 2007 and 2018, including a cohort of 3,164 adults with diagnosed sleep disorders. Depressive symptoms were measured using the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), while recreational physical activity was assessed via metabolic equivalents (METs). The association between physical activity and depressive symptoms was evaluated using multiple linear regression and breakpoint regression models, adjusting for covariates such as sex, age, ethnicity, smoking status, and alcohol consumption.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the fully adjusted model, participants in the highest quartile of recreational physical activity (Q4) exhibited significantly lower depressive symptom scores (Q4: β = -1.01, 95% CI: -1.58 to -0.44, p = 0.0005), indicating that greater physical activity was linked to fewer depressive symptoms. Additional analyses revealed that this inverse relationship was most pronounced for activity levels below 840 MET, which corresponds to approximately 105 min of vigorous recreational physical activity per day or 210 min of moderate-intensity activity per day. The association weakened for activity levels exceeding 840 MET. Subgroup analyses further indicated that the benefits of recreational physical activity were more pronounced in men, individuals aged 40–60 years, and former smokers.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Higher levels of recreational physical activity were associated with significantly reduced depressive symptoms in adults with sleep disorders. The greatest reductions in depressive symptoms were observed at activity levels below 840 MET, which corresponds to approximately 105 min of vigorous recreational physical activity per day or 210 min of moderate-intensity activity per day. Men, individuals aged 40–60 years, and former smokers derived the most benefit from these activity levels.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Depression is a prevalent mental health condition affecting hundreds of millions globally [1]. It profoundly impacts mood, quality of life, and social functioning, and increases the risk of numerous physiological conditions, including cardiovascular disease and metabolic syndrome [2, 3]. The pathogenesis of depression is complex, involving genetic, environmental, and psychological factors [4, 5].Although current pharmacological and psychotherapeutic interventions have demonstrated efficacy in alleviating depressive symptoms, they often face challenges such as side effects, variability in effectiveness, and high relapse rates [6–8]. Consequently, the search for alternative, effective, and cost-efficient interventions is of critical importance.

Recreational physical activity has emerged as a promising non-pharmacological intervention, garnering significant attention in recent year. Encompassing activities like walking, jogging, cycling, and swimming [9], recreational physical activity is highly valued for its accessibility and potential mental health benefits [10]. Numerous studies have highlighted its positive impact on depressive symptoms, mediated through mechanisms such as promoting endorphin release, reducing inflammation, and improving sleep quality [11–13]. Furthermore, recreational physical activity can alleviate depression by reducing anxiety and enhancing overall well-being [14]. Despite these promising findings, the effectiveness of recreational physical activity in mitigating depressive symptoms specifically in adults with sleep disorders remains unclear.

Individuals with sleep disorders are at an elevated risk for depression, given the significant bidirectional relationship between sleep disturbances and depressive symptoms [15]. Sleep problems not only increase the risk of depression but are also exacerbated by existing depressive symptoms, creating a complex cycle that complicates intervention strategies [16]. Given this interplay, addressing depression in those with sleep disorders presents unique challenges. Recreational physical activity, through its potential to improve sleep quality, regulate physiological rhythms, and promote enjoyment, may offer a beneficial avenue for these individuals [17, 18]. However, the specific impact of recreational physical activity on depression in this population remains underexplored, leaving a critical gap in understanding the underlying mechanisms.

This study aims to evaluate the association between recreational physical activity and depression in adults with clinically diagnosed sleep disorders. Through this cross-sectional analysis, we seek to address the existing research gap, provide a scientific basis for mental health intervention strategies targeting this population, and explore the potential of recreational physical activity as an accessible intervention to alleviate depressive symptoms.

sec.title: Ethical approval statement
sec.p: This study uses data from the NHANES database. All data in this database is fully anonymized before access, and therefore, no additional ethical approval was required. The use of the data complies with the ethical guidelines of the database.

sec.title: Informed consent statement
sec.p: As the data used in this study is fully anonymized and no personal identifiers are available, informed consent from participants was not necessary. According to the ethical guidelines of the relevant institutional review board, informed consent was waived for this study.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The study utilized data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES), collected between 2007 and 2018. Initially, a total of 59,842 participants were included. Depressive symptoms were assessed using the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), and recreational physical activity was quantified using metabolic equivalent (MET) scores. Participants with incomplete data were systematically excluded to optimize the study population. Specifically, 28,383 participants with missing PHQ-9 scores were excluded first, followed by 16,298 participants with missing data on recreational physical activity. Additionally, 11,997 participants without a diagnosis of a sleep disorder were excluded. After applying these exclusion criteria, a total of 3,164 participants were included in the final analyses (see Fig. 1 flowchart).

sec.title: Measurement of depression levels
sec.p: Depression levels were assessed using the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), a widely used self-report instrument consisting of nine items that evaluate the frequency of depressive symptoms over the past two weeks [34]. Each item is scored from 0 to 3, with 0 representing ‘not at all’ and 3 representing ‘nearly every day.’ The total score ranges from 0 to 27, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms. Depression severity was categorized based on the total score as follows: no depression (0–4), mild depression (5–9), moderate depression (10–14), moderately severe depression (15–19), and severe depression (20–27). The PHQ-9 has been extensively validated and demonstrates strong reliability and validity for assessing depressive symptoms across diverse populations. In this study, PHQ-9 scores were used to quantify and analyze participants’ depression levels [35].

sec.title: Sleep disorders assessment
sec.p: Sleep disorders were assessed based on whether participants had ever been informed by a physician that they had sleep problems. Specifically, participants were asked during the NHANES survey if they had ever been told by a doctor that they had trouble sleeping. Those who answered affirmatively were classified as having a diagnosed sleep disorder. In this study, only participants with a physician-confirmed diagnosis of a sleep disorder were included to enable a more focused analysis of the relationship between depressive symptoms and recreational physical activity.

sec.title: Recreational physical activities Assessment
sec.p: Recreational physical activity was assessed based on the time participants spent engaging in vigorous and moderate-intensity recreational physical activities. In the NHANES survey, participants were asked to report the number of minutes they engaged in vigorous and moderate-intensity recreational physical activities over the previous 30 days. To calculate the metabolic equivalents (MET) of total recreational physical activity, the time spent in vigorous activity was multiplied by 8 METs, and the time spent in moderate-intensity activity was multiplied by 4 METs [36]. The metabolic equivalent of 8 METs for vigorous activity reflects the higher energy and oxygen demands of such activities, equivalent to eight times the resting metabolic rate. Similarly, a metabolic equivalent of 4 METs for moderate-intensity activity corresponds to four times the resting metabolic rate, indicating a relatively lower energy expenditure [37]. This composite MET score was used to quantify participants’ levels of recreational physical activity, facilitating the analysis of its association with depressive symptoms and sleep disturbances.

sec.title: Assessment of covariates
sec.p: The following covariates were included in this study to control for their potential confounding effects on the relationship between depressive symptoms and recreational physical activity: gender, age, race, smoking status, alcohol use status, diabetes, hypertension, and body mass index (BMI) [38, 39].

Gender was recorded as male or female based on participant self-report. Age was recorded as the participant’s actual age at the time of the survey. Race was categorized based on participant self-identification as one of five groups: Mexican American, Other Hispanic, Non-Hispanic White, Non-Hispanic Black, and Other Race (including multi-racial). Smoking status was categorized as never smoker, former smoker, or current smoker, based on participants’ self-reports. Alcohol use status was similarly assessed by self-report and categorized as never drinker, former drinker, or current drinker. Diabetes and hypertension were assessed based on whether participants had ever received a physician’s diagnosis of either condition. Body mass index (BMI) was calculated from participants’ height and weight using the formula BMI = weight (kg) / height (m)2, and used to assess participants’ weight status. Detailed measurement procedures for all variables are available at www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/. By adjusting for these covariates, the study aimed to minimize the impact of confounding factors and enhance the accuracy and reliability of the results.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: R software was used for all statistical analyses. The study began with a descriptive analysis of the baseline characteristics of the study population. Frequencies and percentages were calculated for categorical variables, while means and standard deviations were reported for continuous variables. To assess the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms, a multiple linear regression model adjusted for covariates was employed. PHQ-9 scores for depressive symptoms were quartile-transformed prior to analysis to address potential non-normality in the distribution.

To further explore the effects of recreational physical activity, stratified analyses were conducted by gender, age, and ethnicity to evaluate subgroup-specific associations. Additionally, sensitivity analyses were performed to assess the robustness of the results with respect to different covariates. All statistical tests were two-sided, with a significance level set at 0.05.

The study also examined the dose-response relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms using generalized additive modeling (GAM) to capture potential non-linear associations. This approach allowed for a more nuanced understanding of complex relationships between variables. All analyses accounted for the NHANES complex sampling design through appropriate weighting, ensuring the representativeness and accuracy of the findings.

sec.title: Baseline situation
sec.p: A total of 3,164 participants were enrolled in this study, divided into four quartile groups (Q1-Q4) based on their metabolic equivalent of recreational physical activity (MET) scores. Demographic and health characteristics across quartile groups are presented in Table 1. The baseline characteristics indicated a gradual decrease in participants’ age with increasing MET scores (P < 0.001), with mean ages of 56.11, 53.16, 48.89, and 43.49 years for quartiles Q1 to Q4, respectively. The poverty income ratio (PIR) also increased with rising MET levels, with PIR values of 2.39, 2.94, 2.90, and 2.94 for Q1 to Q4, respectively (P < 0.001). Body mass index (BMI) progressively decreased across quartile groups, from 30.85 kg/m² in Q1 to 28.68 kg/m² in Q4 (P < 0.001). The proportion of males increased significantly with higher levels of recreational physical activity, from 35.81% in Q1 to 59.20% in Q4 (P < 0.001). The racial distribution remained relatively consistent across quartile groups, predominantly composed of non-Hispanic White participants, with proportions of 50.13%, 56.26%, 52.08%, and 49.09% in Q1 to Q4, respectively (P = 0.181).

table-wrap-foot.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; PHQ-9, Patient Health Questionnaire-9

sec.p: There was a trend towards higher educational attainment across quartile groups, with the proportion of participants holding a university degree or higher increasing from 20.31% in Q1 to 33.85% in Q4 (P < 0.001). The proportion of unmarried participants varied slightly across quartiles, with 25.97% in Q4 compared to 12.76% in Q1 (P < 0.001). The proportion of never smokers increased with rising MET levels, with 46.80%, 51.86%, 52.24%, and 50.91% in Q1 to Q4, respectively (P < 0.001). Similarly, the proportion of current drinkers rose from 75.70% in Q1 to 89.04% in Q4 (P < 0.001).The prevalence of cardiovascular disease decreased gradually from 19.95% in Q1 to 8.65% in Q4 (P = 0.877). The prevalence of hypertension and diabetes mellitus also showed significant declines with increasing MET levels, with hypertension decreasing from 54.73% in Q1 to 34.47% in Q4 and diabetes mellitus from 20.72% in Q1 to 7.43% in Q4 (P < 0.001).

Overall, baseline characteristics revealed notable improvements in health indicators with increasing levels of recreational physical activity, including lower age, reduced BMI, and decreased prevalence of cardiovascular disease, hypertension, and diabetes. These findings suggest that higher levels of recreational physical activity may be associated with multiple health benefits.

sec.title: Association between recreational activities and Depressive symptoms in adults with diagnosed sleep disorders
sec.p: The present study further analyzed the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms in adults diagnosed with sleep disorders. Table 2 presents the effects of different levels of recreational physical activity (Q1-Q4) on depressive symptoms across the unadjusted, adjusted I, and adjusted II models.

caption.p: The association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms in adults with diagnosed Sleep disorders

table-wrap-foot.p: Adjust I, Adjusted for Gender, Age and Race;
Adjust II, Adjusted for Gender, Age, Race, High blood pressure, Diabetes, BMI, Smoking status, Alcohol status

Note: “Ref” refers to Q1 (first quartile) group, with Q2, Q3, and Q4 representing second, third, and fourth quartiles, respectively. These quartiles are used as reference categories for comparison in the analysis

sec.p: In the unadjusted model, higher quartiles of recreational physical activity (Q3 and Q4) were significantly associated with lower depressive symptom scores compared to the lowest quartile (Q1) (Q3: β = -0.86, 95% CI: -1.40, -0.31, P = 0.0020; Q4: β = -1.01, 95% CI: -1.57, -0.44, P = 0.0005), suggesting that greater engagement in recreational physical activity was linked to fewer depressive symptoms. The association between the second quartile (Q2) and depressive symptoms did not reach statistical significance (β = -0.51, 95% CI: -1.08, 0.07, P = 0.0869). The association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms remained significant in quartiles Q3 and Q4 in the adjusted I model (adjusted for gender, age, and ethnicity) (Q3: β = -1.07, 95% CI: -1.61, -0.53, P = 0.0001; Q4: β = -1.36, 95% CI: -1.93, -0.79, P < 0.0001), while the association for Q2 did not reach statistical significance (β = -0.50, 95% CI: -1.07, 0.07, P = 0.0854).

In the adjusted II model (further adjusted for hypertension, diabetes, BMI, smoking status, and alcohol consumption), the negative associations between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms remained significant for Q3 and Q4 (Q3: β = -0.73, 95% CI: -1.27, -0.20, P = 0.0073; Q4: β = -1.01, 95% CI: -1.58, -0.44, P = 0.0005), while the association for Q2 remained non-significant (β = -0.19, 95% CI: -0.75, 0.37, P = 0.5043)

Overall, the findings indicate that higher levels of recreational physical activity, particularly in the third and fourth quartiles, were significantly associated with lower depressive symptom scores among adults with sleep disorders, even after adjusting for multiple covariates. This suggests a robust relationship between recreational physical activity and reduced depressive symptoms in this population.

sec.title: Analysis of the non-linear relationship between MET and PHQ-9 depressive symptoms
sec.p: To further understand the non-linear relationship between recreational physical activity (measured in metabolic equivalents, MET) and depressive symptoms (PHQ-9 scores), breakpoint regression analyses were conducted. Table 3 presents the results of the breakpoint regression model for MET on PHQ-9 scores, and the fitted curve between MET and PHQ-9 scores is shown in Fig. 2.

In Model I, the linear effect of recreational physical activity was significant (β = -0.00, 95% CI: -0.00, -0.00, P = 0.0046), indicating that recreational physical activity was significantly associated with lower depressive symptoms, albeit with a modest effect size. In Model II, a breakpoint was identified (K = 840), before and after which the effect of recreational physical activity on depressive symptoms differed significantly.

caption.p: Breakpoint regression analysis of MET on PHQ-9
The fitted curve between MET and PHQ-9 scores

sec.p: Specifically, when MET was below the breakpoint (K = 840), there was a significant negative association between recreational physical activity and PHQ-9 scores (β = -0.00, 95% CI: -0.00, -0.00, P < 0.0001), In contrast, this negative association was significantly attenuated once MET exceeded the breakpoint (β = 0.00, 95% CI: -0.00, 0.00, P = 0.0849) and did not reach statistical significance. The difference between the two zones, before and after the breakpoint, was significant (difference β = 0.00, 95% CI: 0.00, 0.00, P = 0.0003). This finding further supports the non-linear relationship between MET and PHQ-9 scores. The log-likelihood ratio test results (3.67, 95% CI: 3.30, 4.03, P < 0.001) indicated that the breakpoint model provided a better fit for explaining the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms compared to a simple linear model.

The phenomenon of β = 0 but statistically significant warrants further clarification, as several factors contribute to this observation. In large datasets such as NHANES, even very small effects can become statistically significant due to the increased statistical power derived from the large sample size. While the effect size may appear negligible, the high power of the analysis allows for the detection of small effects. Additionally, the breakpoint regression analysis reveals a non-linear relationship between physical activity and depressive symptoms. At lower levels of activity, there is a measurable effect, but once the activity level surpasses a certain threshold, the effect diminishes, likely due to diminishing returns at higher activity levels. The log-likelihood ratio test (P < 0.001) further confirms that the breakpoint model fits the data better than a linear model, reinforcing the non-linear nature of the relationship between physical activity and depressive symptoms. In summary, although the regression coefficients may seem small or even close to zero, their statistical significance should not be overlooked. These findings underscore the complexity of the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms, with the breakpoint model offering a more nuanced understanding of how different levels of activity influence mental health outcomes.

In summary, the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms exhibits a complex, non-linear pattern. At activity levels below 840 MET, increases in recreational physical activity appear to be effective in alleviating depressive symptoms. However, when activity levels exceed 840 MET, the marginal benefits diminish significantly. These findings suggest that moderate levels of recreational physical activity may represent the most effective strategy for reducing depressive symptoms.

sec.title: Subgroup analyses and interaction tests
sec.p: Subgroup analyses and interaction tests were conducted to assess the impact of demographic and health characteristics on the association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms (Table 4).

caption.p: Subgroup analysis of the association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms in Diagnosed Sleep disorders

table-wrap-foot.p: Adjust II, Adjusted for Gender, Age, Race, High blood pressure, Diabetes, BMI, Smoking status, Alcohol status
Note: “Ref” refers to the reference group in the Crude model, with all other subgroups being compared to this group in the analysis

sec.p: In terms of gender, the inverse relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms was statistically significant in men (β = -0.0006, 95% CI: -0.0011, -0.0001, P = 0.0105), but not in women (P = 0.8769). The interaction P value for gender was 0.0841, suggesting that gender differences may carry some statistical significance. When examining race, the strongest negative association was observed among non-Hispanic whites (β = -0.0007, 95% CI: -0.0011, -0.0002, P = 0.0020), with no significant associations detected in other racial groups (P > 0.05). The interaction P value of 0.5074 indicates a non-significant difference between races. Age-related analyses revealed that recreational physical activity was most strongly associated with a reduction in depressive symptoms in participants aged 40–60 years (β = -0.0010, 95% CI: -0.0017, -0.0004, P = 0.0013). No significant associations were found in other age groups (P > 0.05), with the interaction P value for age standing at 0.1052.

Regarding alcohol consumption, current drinkers showed a significant inverse association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms (β = -0.0006, 95% CI: -0.0010, -0.0002, P = 0.0030), although the interaction P value of 0.6010 suggests that drinking status did not significantly modulate this relationship. In terms of smoking status, the strongest negative association was seen in former smokers (β = -0.0012, 95% CI: -0.0018, -0.0005, P = 0.0005), with no significant effects observed in never smokers or current smokers (P > 0.05). The interaction P value for smoking status was 0.0442, indicating a statistically significant moderating effect. With respect to BMI, recreational physical activity was significantly associated with lower depressive symptoms in individuals with a BMI ≥ 30 (β = -0.0008, 95% CI: -0.0014, -0.0002, P = 0.0092), while no significant associations were detected in participants with lower BMI values (P > 0.05). The interaction P value for BMI was 0.3652.

Overall, these subgroup analyses demonstrate that the effects of recreational physical activity on depressive symptoms vary across populations with different characteristics. In particular, more significant associations were observed in men, individuals aged 40–60, and former smokers. Interaction tests further suggest that sex, age, and smoking status may influence the relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms to a certain degree.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The findings of this study reveal a significant negative association between higher levels of recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms, characterized by complex nonlinear dynamics. Increases in recreational physical activity were significantly linked to reductions in depressive symptoms at activity levels below 840 MET, while this negative association was notably attenuated at levels exceeding 840 MET. Subgroup analyses further highlighted heterogeneity in this relationship across sex, age, ethnicity, alcohol consumption, and smoking status, suggesting that certain populations—particularly men, individuals aged 40–60 years, and former smokers—may derive greater benefits from recreational physical activity.

In comparison to previous research on the relationship between recreational physical activity and mental health, this study uniquely focuses on adults with sleep disorders. This aligns with prior work, including meta-analysis by Matthew Pearce and Francesco Recchia, which reported that regular physical activity significantly alleviated depressive symptoms [19, 20]. However, the present study extends these findings by identifying a differential impact of activity levels on depressive symptoms using a breakpoint regression model. This non-linear effect suggests that moderate levels of recreational activity may offer the most benefit in reducing depressive symptoms, while higher activity levels may confer diminishing returns, consistent with the observations of Paluska and Paolucci regarding the relationship between physical activity and mental health outcomes [21, 22].

Consistent with the findings of Eunjung Lim and Laia Maynou on the influence of demographic characteristics, the present study’s subgroup analyses revealed that recreational physical activity has varying effects across specific populations [23, 24]. In particular, males, individuals aged 40–60, and those with a history of smoking appeared to benefit more significantly from recreational physical activity. This aligns with previous research highlighting the role of lifestyle factors in physical activity outcomes [13], particularly among middle-aged men. Notably, the mental health benefits of physical activity were more pronounced in individuals with sleep disturbances, further emphasizing the relevance and applicability of recreational physical activity in these populations.

In summary, by examining both the non-linear relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms and its differential effects across subgroups, this study offers new insights into developing targeted mental health interventions for adults with sleep disorders. To maximize the positive impact on mental health, future interventions should focus on promoting moderate levels of activity while accounting for individual factors such as gender, age, and lifestyle.

The mechanisms by which recreational physical activity alleviates depressive symptoms in adults with sleep disorders are not yet fully understood, though several physiological and psychological pathways may contribute to this association. First, recreational physical activity may enhance mood and alleviate depressive symptoms by increasing levels of endorphins and dopamine—neurotransmitters critical to feelings of pleasure and reward [25, 26]. Moderate physical activity is known to stimulate the release of these neurotransmitters, resulting in an antidepressant effect.

Second, physical activity may indirectly reduce depressive symptoms by improving sleep quality. Research highlights a significant bidirectional relationship between sleep disturbances and depressive symptoms [15, 27]. Recreational physical activity can help regulate physiological rhythms, shorten sleep onset latency, and increase the duration of deep sleep. These improvements in sleep quality are particularly valuable for individuals with sleep disorders, as better sleep can mitigate depressive symptoms driven by chronic sleep deprivation. Additionally, recreational physical activity may exert its beneficial effects by reducing inflammation and modulating the stress response [28]. Sleep disorders are often associated with chronic inflammation and heightened stress [29], and physical activity has been shown to lower pro-inflammatory markers and reduce cortisol levels [30]. These anti-inflammatory and stress-reducing effects can contribute to improved mental health.

Finally, the social and psychological aspects of recreational physical activity should not be overlooked [31, 32]. Participation in such activities often involves social interaction, which can provide valuable psychological support and emotional connection for individuals with sleep disorders. This social engagement helps reduce feelings of isolation and depression, fostering psychological resilience. Thus, recreational physical activity is not only a means of exercise but also a pathway to social support and mental well-being.

This study possesses several notable strengths. First, the large sample size derived from the nationally representative NHANES database enhances the generalizability and representativeness of the findings. Second, the use of a breakpoint regression model offers a novel approach to capturing the nonlinear relationship between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms, allowing for a more nuanced understanding of how different activity levels influence mental health outcomes. Additionally, the detailed subgroup analyses provide valuable insights into the heterogeneity of this relationship across various demographic characteristics, laying the groundwork for the development of individualized intervention strategies.

This study has several limitations. First, both depressive symptoms and recreational physical activity were self-reported, which may introduce recall and social desirability biases, potentially affecting the accuracy of the data. While self-reported measures are commonly used in large-scale epidemiological studies like NHANES and have been validated in similar cohorts, these biases could either underestimate or overestimate the observed associations [33]. To strengthen the findings, future research could incorporate more objective measures, such as activity trackers or clinical assessments. Additionally, as a secondary analysis of the NHANES dataset, this study is susceptible to the risk of false positives due to multiple testing. The large number of statistical comparisons increases the likelihood of Type I errors, and although confounders were adjusted for, no formal correction for multiple testing was applied. Future research should address this limitation by applying appropriate statistical corrections or adopting prospective study designs to further validate the results. Furthermore, the cross-sectional nature of the study prevents causal inferences. Although the study suggests an association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms, it cannot establish causality, and the observed relationship may be influenced by reverse causality. The lack of longitudinal data limits the ability to assess the directionality of this relationship. To better understand causal pathways, future studies should employ longitudinal designs and aim to identify whether increasing physical activity can serve as a preventive or therapeutic intervention for depressive symptoms, particularly in individuals with sleep disorders.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study demonstrates a significant inverse association between recreational physical activity and depressive symptoms in adults with sleep disorders, with the effect being particularly strong at higher levels of activity. Recreational physical activity shows promise as a non-pharmacological intervention for alleviating depressive symptoms in this population. By leveraging the large NHANES database and employing innovative methods such as breakpoint regression and smoothed curve analyses, we quantified the non-linear relationship between physical activity and depressive symptoms. Our findings suggest that higher levels of recreational physical activity, up to approximately 105 min of vigorous activity per day (or 210 min of moderate-intensity activity per day), are associated with reduced depressive symptoms, offering preliminary recommendations for moderate activity levels. This insight paves the way for developing interventions tailored to the needs of different demographic groups.

Subgroup analyses further revealed that the benefits of recreational physical activity were more pronounced among men, middle-aged adults (aged 40–60), and former smokers. These findings highlight the importance of personalizing interventions based on gender, age, and lifestyle to enhance the effectiveness of mental health strategies. In addition to mitigating depressive symptoms, recreational physical activity may enhance overall mental health in patients with sleep disorders by improving sleep quality, reducing inflammation, and modulating stress responses.

However, due to the cross-sectional nature of this study, a causal relationship could not be definitively established. Future research should adopt longitudinal designs to explore the long-term effects of recreational physical activity on depressive symptoms while accounting for potential confounders, such as diet and life stress. Moreover, as this study relied on self-reported data, future studies should aim to validate these findings using more objective measures.

notes.title: Author contributions

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets used in this study are publicly available from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) database. The data can be accessed at: https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/index.htm.

notes.title: Consent for publication
notes.p: Not Applicable. No identifiable personal data or images are presented in this study.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
Conflict of interest
notes.p: We declare that we have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
